results.title: Reading for what? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and David Allen
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Early years at school”.
Deals analytically with areas of importance and concern to teachers of children aged three to nine. Examines the question of why most children learn to read but do not always read for pleasure or purpose.

results.title: Reading for meaning: the Goodman Model (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Tom Manefield and Karl McPhee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch your language”
Understanding the reading process. Professors Ken and Yetta Goodman discuss the problems of the teaching of reading with a class of teachers in Australia. Docments some of their main propositions relating to language in use, miscue analysis and reading. Stresses the need to focus on the strengths of children and not simply the weaknesses.
Suitable for teacher level.

results.title: Reading between the lines: the inside story of a daily newspaper
results.creator_credit: Video Education Australasia and Image Link
results.brief_description: Uses a day at the “Melbourne Age” to show how a daily paper is assembled, and its role in competition with TV and radio. In particular, looks at the news gathering process, the roles of reporting, editorial and production staff, the editorial process, reasons for positioning articles, the use of photographs and graphics, the production process, and the role of advertising. No other credits available.

results.title: Reading between the lines: live at six o'clock
results.creator_credit: Video Education Australasia and Image Link
results.brief_description: This program takes us behind the scenes for a critical look at the processes and practices that shape television news and current affairs programs. It explores the gathering and processing of TV news as well as some of the strengths and weaknesses of the television news media. It discusses the role of the Director of News, Chief of Staff, TV journalist, Anchor/ Presenter, Current Affairs host, and the use of various media technology such as the weather map, auto cue etc.. No other credits available.

results.title: Reading between the lines: inside the stories
results.creator_credit: Video Education Australasia and Image Link
results.brief_description: Looks at the content of our newspapers, through interviews with journalists and editors. It addresses the use of language, background, an article’s purpose, sources of information and the intended audience. No other credits available.

results.title: Reading Australian Film
results.brief_description: This is a film about how to watch films. The reason for making a film is to tell a story by using vision and sound. The finished version often taps into experiences we ourselves have had in real life. But film is not reality… it is a constructed medium which conveys messages of fact, fiction and emotion.

results.title: Reading activities with young children (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, Open University and Edward Milner
results.brief_description: Examines a variety of reading activities going on in one classroom in an infant school in Cheshire. Shows a sample of activities in pet corner. We also see part of storytime for the youngest children and children reading to the teacher.

results.title: Readicut rugs
results.brief_description: Shows the birth of the world’s wool industry in England. Takes the viewer through the stages of rug-making from selected English wool to the manufacturing processes.
